1118288174415929345.text: 2/ Each reserve is a smart contract that is controlled by reserve admin who deployed it. Reserves vary in supported tokens, liquidity and conversion prices. When a user wants to exchange one token for another, Kyber scans all reserves to pick the cheapest one."

1123313276731965440.text: What I really like about it is "boost" create DAI, buy ETH, add ETH to CDP all in one step. Or "repay" withdraw ETH, buy DAI, payback to CDP also in one step. It uses @KyberNetwork to do the exchange. Felt like magic when I tried it.

1122683073479368706.text: @KyberNetwork using @metamask_io was a quick and relatively easy way to convert DAI to ETH. I tried 4 other methods but was unable to get any of them to work.

1120321265271595009.text: 2/ We outline the specs to implement Reserve-based and standardized liquidity models and APIs on these chains, to facilitate liquidity between different stakeholders in their respective ecosystems

1120323064929980416.text: 4/ Building on past work on cross-chain communications (e.g. PeaceRelay, Waterloo), we envision the use of relay bridges to facilitate cross-chain swaps and create a connected liquidity network across Kyber deployments on different chains

1120318284467802112.text:
Together with our new website, we release the first version of the Kyber protocol paper, where we formalize Kyber as a liquidity protocol that can be implemented on any smart contract-enabled blockchain to power on-chain token swaps. 

Learn more:https://blog.kyber.network/kyber-protocol-widening-kyber-adoption-across-blockchains-170e4051094d …

1120321564996554752.text:
3/ 4 aspects that drive the standardized liquidity model: 
Interface for reserves to add liquidity to the liquidity pool
On-chain liquidity & conversion rates
Single endpoint for takers to easily execute on-chain transactions
Network maintainers for each chain deployment
